segments.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, mahāpathavī parikkhayaṃ pariyādānaṃ gaccheyya, ṭhapetvā satta kolaṭṭhimattiyo guḷikā.
segments.en: “Mendicants, suppose the great earth was worn away and eroded except for seven clay balls the size of jujube seeds.

segments.pli: katamaṃ nu kho bahutaraṃ, yaṃ vā mahāpathaviyā parikkhīṇaṃ pariyādiṇṇaṃ yā vā satta kolaṭṭhimattiyo guḷikā avasiṭṭhā”ti?
segments.en: Which is more: the great earth that has been worn away and eroded, or the seven clay balls the size of jujube seeds that are left?”

segments.pli: “Etadeva, bhante, bahutaraṃ, mahāpathaviyā, yadidaṃ parikkhīṇaṃ pariyādiṇṇaṃ;
segments.en: “Sir, the great earth that has been worn away and eroded is certainly more.
The seven clay balls the size of jujube seeds are tiny.

segments.pli: Neva satimaṃ kalaṃ upenti na sahassimaṃ kalaṃ upenti na satasahassimaṃ kalaṃ upenti mahāpathaviyā parikkhīṇaṃ pariyādiṇṇaṃ upanidhāya satta kolaṭṭhimattiyo guḷikā avasiṭṭhā”ti.
segments.en: Compared to the great earth that has been worn away and eroded, it’s not nearly a hundredth, a thousandth, or a hundred thousandth part.”
“In the same way, for a noble disciple, the suffering that’s over and done with is more …”

suttaplex.blurb: For someone who has seen the truth, the suffering eliminated is like the great earth; what remains is like seven balls of clay.
